newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan thanks Peru, says was not told of storming.
newsitem.headline: Japan thanks Peru, says was not told of storming.

text.p: Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said on Wednesday he regretted he was not informed of Peru's storming of the residence of the Japanese ambassador to end a long siege but said no one could criticise the move.
"We unfortunately were not told of the operation before the move. I regret this, but we thank the Peruvian authorities for seizing the chance," Hashimoto told a news conference.
Japan has persistently demanded a peaceful end to the hostage drama, but maintained that they would stand by the Peruvian government.
Hashimoto said all 24 Japanese hostages, including Japanese ambassador Morihisa Aoki, were rescued soon after Peruvian troops stormed his residence after a four-month ordeal.
"We were truly hoping for a peaceful solution, but that is a notion of someone who is far away at a place where there is a 14-hour time difference," Hashimoto said.
"How can any one criticise President (Alberto) Fujimori? It is not important whether we had prior knowledge of the move. The important thing is that the hostages were freed."
Hashimoto said he will send Foreign Minister Yukihiko Ikeda to Lima as soon as possible to consult with Peruvian authorities.
He said was awakened by aides minutes after the first shots were fired by Peruvian troops storming the residence, which started at around 5.23 a.m. Japan time (2023 GMT).
All Japanese television stations covered the event live from Lima.
Hashimoto also offered condolences over the deaths of some Peruvian troops in the operation.
"We have not confirmed this, but it appears some of the soldiers died. We offer our deepest thanks and condolences."
On Tuesday, Hashimoto received a letter from top mediator Roman Catholic Archbishop Juan Luis Cipriani urging the Japanese government to press for a peaceful end to the crisis.
Hashimoto's aides said Cipriani's plea was based on concerns that hardliners in Fujimori's government had put pressure on the Peruvian government to storm the residence.
